qas.question: What may be used to weight the importance of components?
What are often called psychoacoustic models?
What is the process called when a signal is masked by another signal separated by time?
What may be used to weight the importance of cosine?
What are often called psychoacoustic masking?
What is the process when a signal is masked by another signal separated by contours?
What is the phenomenon wherein a signal is masked by another signal separated by threshold?
What is a transform that a compression frequency might use?

context: To determine what information in an audio signal is perceptually irrelevant, most lossy compression algorithms use transforms such as the <b7_0>modified discrete cosine transform<b7_0/> (MDCT) to convert time domain sampled waveforms into a transform domain. Once transformed, typically into the frequency domain, component frequencies can be allocated bits according to how audible they are. Audibility of spectral components calculated using the absolute threshold of hearing and the principles of <b6_0>simultaneous masking<b6_0/>—the phenomenon wherein a signal is masked by another signal separated by frequency—and, in some cases, <a2_0><b5_0>temporal masking<b5_0/><a2_0/>—where a signal is masked by another signal separated by time. <a0_0><b3_0>Equal-loudness contours<b3_0/><a0_0/> may also be used to weight the perceptual importance of components. <a1_0><b4_0>Models of the human ear-brain<b4_0/><a1_0/> combination incorporating such effects are often called psychoacoustic models.
